description: From Middle English sherte, shurte, schirte, from Old English sċyrte (“a short garment; skirt; kirtle”), from Proto-West Germanic *skurtijā, from Proto-Germanic *skurtijǭ (“a short garment, skirt, apron”), from *skurtaz (“short”).

Cognate with Saterland Frisian Schoarte (“apron”), Dutch schort (“apron”), German Schürze (“apron”), Danish skjorte (“shirt”), Norwegian skjorte (“shirt”), Swedish skjorta (“shirt”), Faroese skjúrta (“shirt”), Icelandic skyrta (“shirt”).
English skirt is a parallel formation from Old Norse; which is a doublet of short, from the same ultimate source.

entries.meaning: An article of clothing that is worn on the upper part of the body, and often has sleeves, either long or short, that cover the arms.
examples: It can take a while to learn how to iron a shirt properly.

entries.meaning: An interior lining in a blast furnace.
A member of the shirt-wearing team in a shirts and skins game.
An article of clothing that is worn on the upper part of the body, and often has sleeves, either long or short, that cover the arms.
An interior lining in a blast furnace.
A member of the shirt-wearing team in a shirts and skins game.

description: From Middle English sherten, shirten (also shorten), from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: shirt (third-person singular simple present shirts, present participle shirting, simple past and past participle shirted)

entries.meaning: To cover or clothe with a shirt, or as if with a shirt.
examples: Ah! for so many souls, as but this morn / Were clothed with flesh, and warm’d with vital blood / But naked now, or shirted just with air.
